reviewText: I found this film to be an enjoyable experience to watch. A film of a stage play with for the most part, only two characters, the stage is set to go on an interesting journey! The two starts when a very straight, sweaty, rugged looking carpenter, Doug (Robert Mammana) meets on purpose a gay guy, named Guy, (Matthew Jaeger) sitting on a park bench while reading a book "The Works Of Plato"The relationship between the two deepens....and moves from sex to love, and a very surprising ending!This is a film of a stage play that is simple, unusual, and works. It may not appeal to everybody, but I liked it...I liked it a lot!
Title: N/A

reviewText: An excellent adaptation of a stage play that is a discussion of Plato's ideas on love and redemption. It revolves around two characters who deal with very real scenarios of lust, love, betrayal and finally understanding of their humanity. Relationships may start one way but never end up the way that the participants think they will. Will the construction worker, in the end, finally understand what his former girlfriend was trying to explain to him all along about the meaning of self and love?  Will the gay guy rise above his baser instincts and find what he eagerly seeks?  I highly recommend buying the dvd to find out.

reviewText: Guy (Matthew Jaeger) is reading Plato in the park, when a sweaty, hunky "straight" construction worker, Doug (Robert Mammana), sits down beside him and makes small talk.  When his conversation quickly gets to how he has nothing to do for the rest of his lunch hour, and he's very horny, one doesn't need to be psychic to figure where this is going. It does, but not the way you would expect."Just Say Love" (2009) is the screen adaptation of a play about loneliness and a unique perspective on relationships, whether they consider them acquaintances, friendships or love.  Guy and Doug start off clearly wanting very different things out of their meetings, but it evolves - over a period of many months - into something that is mutually rewarding and satisfying to both of them, but not in the way they first expected. It's a sweet (and perhaps a bit contrived) story, produced as it would be on a small stage, with minimal props, just the two characters (thankfully, played by skilled actors who do their best with the occasional eye-rolling dialogue), and some imagination needed in absence of tangible props (It took me a second to realize they were both admiring a "painting" that was just an empty frame.)  Not everyone's cup of herbal tea, but a welcome respite from the average gay love story.Produced by Here!TV, and likely to be on their service eventually, the film is unrated but would likely be an R. DVD has no extras except chapter stops. I give it four stars out of five, including an extra star for originality.
summary: Unique look at a relationship between two men
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a rather cold, low budget stage play which involves only two characters throughout. There is the part of a baby shown once but spoken of throughout the play, and a brief involvement of a man whose face you don't see and the brief appearance of a girlfriend spoken of throughout whose face you also never see. The rest of the play involves only the two characters, Guy, (Matthew Jaeger) a gay man who is lonely and looking for true love as he has always imagined it to be, while he mourns the death of his cat; and Doug (Robert Mammana) a straight man who is in a relationship that he feels is going nowhere. Doug is horny and looking for physical fulfillment, but underneath it all he is also looking for a way to reconcile a lost, unfulfilled love from his youth. The stage is mostly dark and utilizes spotlights for emphasis. The props are a bit weird as is the whole play. It is based on philosophical beliefs which are rather obscure and largely based on the writings of Plato. There is somewhat of a story but not really a good one and rather unbelievable. Everytime the stage would go dark I was left hoping the play was over and wouldn't drag out any longer. I bought it, so I was committed to watching it through to the end, but that part seemed as if it would never come. There were a few good messages throughout, but not many. Both actors done a good job portraying their characters. Robert Mammana is a very good looking man who's acting was rather good. Matthew Jaeger however is a rather unattractive man who overacted his part a bit too much. It was ok, but definitely nothing I would ever want to see again. There is a scene which revolves around a new imaginary cat which the viewer never sees. I was largely disappointed and unless you are a vegetarian, or a follower of Plato or other so-caled philosophers, you will probably find it as boring and strange as I did. I will rate it with three stars given that it wasn't bad as a stage play, as stage plays go. It is not a "film" or "movie" and really offers no real entertainment value. It is a "play" and I suppose is intended as an art form. It is a poorly written script and a bit too "out there" for my tastes.
summary: Just say NO......... don't be duped by the deceptive reviews.

reviewText: This two-man theatrical production on video is intelligently written, beautifully acted, and emotionally powerful!  Within a sparse suggestion of settings that overlap on stage, the two characters hold the reader spell-bound with their probing exchanges throughout the play.  The richness of the content encourages multiple viewings as few other productions do.  This is a very uplifting script beautifully brought to fruition.

reviewText: If you are seeking a film that has many special effects, lots of action, multiple story lines and many characters contributing their stories to the plot, forget this film!  "Just say Love" is a film (it certainly has the appearance of a filmed stage play) that has meager scenery, story line and action.  What it does have is what I call heart (aka love and romance)The film "Just say Love" has only two characters that are totally the opposite of each other and initially just sexually attracted to one another.  There is hunky Doug (wonderfully acted by Robert Mamma) and nerdy Guy, that's wonderfully acted by Mathew Jaeger, coming together and after just lust finding themselves  on a very "bumpy" road to love with both having lots of "needs".  However, love does come and how it does come, after a very rough start, makes for a highly entertaining film. Trust me; if you are a "romantic", you will no doubt enjoy this film with its highly improbable but romantic ending and all.  I certainly did.

reviewText: Of course gay people would prefer, for a change, to see a gay movie that ends happily. This is one that does. But at the expense of a stage setting presentation, stilted dialogue, and tiresome vegan and New Age ideas. The true interest is in the theme of an essentially straight man--a muscular working man at that--who becomes full-time partner of his gay admirer. Relationships like these have existed for a long time, but closeted. And the gay partner might find daily living with someone with a background so remote from his a serious limitation after a while. But the film keeps to the perfect ending, and that's okay, I guess.

reviewText: Basically what you are watching is a filmed version of a stage play adapted to a movie. It is not like most films I have seen in the past like "RENT Live" , but it somehow manages to come together in a very interesting and watchable way.This movie/play is about a gay man who meets a married and somewhat confused construction worker outside of his apartment. As you might guess, it leads to a relationship between the two, but the wife who you never see is not aware. The construction worker is torn between the two and he can not really ever come to the conclusion if he is gay or not. I don't want to give too much away, so I will leave it there.I think this movie was pretty good in the fact that as one reviewer already noted, it has a plot, a deep subject matter, and yes most gay movies are mostly either too over the top, or its like they ran out of money and it just ends leaving the viewer saying "what the hell happened". There are not too many movies in this genre that are great films. That is unfortunate, but the films are getting better every year.If this type of subject matter interests you, then you should give it a chance. At least do yourself a favor and rent it from Amazon Prime , but I am glad we own this movie
Title: N/A

reviewText: For a love story, this movie is oddly formal, stylized and cold. It is a lot like kabuki, the highly formal, highly stylized classical Japanese dance/drama. It is the most tightly scripted and choreographed movie I have ever seen: not one word, not one gesture by either character is spontaneous. It feels more like very expertly executed computer animation than like two human men falling in love.I think the basic problem is the Platonic philosophy that dominates and runs insistently through the whole play. That philosophy - that the body is only a shallow, essentially meaningless reflection of spiritual reality - is itself so cold and so formal that it practically demands a treatment like this.That is sad. This could have been touching and meaningful, but it ends up being just very well executed technique on the part of everyone involved: the director, actors, set designer, cinematographer, etc. Like kabuki, it is fascinating to watch, but the fascination is purely intellectual, just like Plato. It is a peculiar and unsatisfying way to tell a love story.
summary: An oddly formal and cold love story

reviewText: .......ending.  And you know what?  We deserve it!((Here is my approach to obtaining/reviewing Gay content films.  Simply, it's seeking the holy grail of that genre, or looking for the "Addictive Film"---that movie one returns to time and again).  Selection/purchase comes from finding new releases by favorite directors/screenwriters, and from your comments at major online DVD sales or review sites.  Rarely, I come across the "Addictive," those watchable every couple of months or oftener (see below starred *** area for a list......and some "near-addictive" as well).  Thanks for sticking with me so far.))Having seen years of gay film productions (particularly romances) on video tape, Laser and DVD, for me most have been crap (any disagreement?).  BUT....this one can take a proud and high position in the Top-12 of gay dramas.  Excellent writing/conversion to screen, great staging.......they're in here.  Still and all, it's Matthew Jaeger (Guy / Guido) and Robert Mammana (Doug) who breathe life into this work and into Us as we watch. Captivated and drawn into their simple lives, we see them become Us---you and me.  That's right, who out here wouldn't want a man of openness, raw needs, funniness......wouldn't "physically" want such a man as Doug?  Would anyone of us turn down a Guy's perceptiveness, depth of feeling, and indefinable ability to draw us out of ourselves?So in the end, this whole thing (this "Just Say Love") has fallen to and been carried on the shoulders of these two amazing actors---actors who didn't just learn lines....but who lived their parts.  In tribute to them, I feel compelled to say I can think of no other past performers in gay filmdom who could have done better.  Can you?***This film will join others on my "Addictive" shelf:  "Just a Question of Love" / "Shelter" / "Ciao" / "Brokeback Mountain" / "A Single Man" / "Boy Culture" / "All Over the Guy" / "Second Skin (Unrated Version)" / "The Man I Love" / "The Man of My Life" (maybe for older gay viewers) / "Oh Happy Day [dvd]" / "Fashion Victims (Reine Geschmacksache)"
summary: We're given an Enchanted Fairytale....with a happy........

reviewText: This is a story of sexual desire, loneliness, friendship, and love between a gay man and a straight man.  Although the story contains erotic elements, it is essentially a cerebral story rooted in the conversations and emotions of the two men.  If you enjoy films that focus on dialogue and psychological development, you may well enjoy this.  If you're looking for sex or action, it's probably not your film.  That's not to say that the two leads aren't attractive--they are.  And they are also excellent actors.  The story is filmed on a stage set a la "Our Town."  I enjoyed the movie a great deal, but it's clearly not for everyone.

reviewText: "Just say love" proves that it is possible to create a gay theme movie with good acting and not bad directing.The concept itself (similar to "Dogville" by van Trier) is very interesting. The whole film is shot on a theatre-like-stage. The art direction is quite minimalistic, but it leaves space for the imagination.The actors deliver very mature and eye catching performances.There is one thing which made me deduct 1 star from my rating. It is the love scene, or rather its ending. The scene is beautiful, but the odd and unnecessary shots after the climax ruined the whole impression.Higly recommended.

reviewText: The concept is unique in that the main characters Guy (gay) and Doug (straight) meet in what seems to be a quick sexual  encounter. Quickly the conversation turns to a discussion of Plato's philosophy which Guy is studying and yoga teachings which Doug's girlfriend Gida professes. During the film, both characters grow in their understandings of human growth and relationships. It is a film of a stage play and uses theater sets, action techniques, and lighting. It is a beautifully told story and the actors are excellent. I was surprised by the ending. I highly recommend this film.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Essentially a filmed version of a stage play, "Just Say Love" is the story of the unlikely romance between a philosophy-spouting gay man, Guy (Matthew Jaeger), and Doug (Robert Mammana), a rough, tough straight construction worker.  The relationship begins as a one-time sexual encounter (is Doug curious or simply in need of a lunchtime sex fix?).  But over a period of months it blossoms into friendship and finally love.The script tends to be quite repetitive.  After all, how many times do we need to hear Guy mutter "Just say love, just say love"?  At only 75 minutes the film seems to drag.  There is little in the way of action, but lots and lots of talk.  Along the way we are treated to liberal doses of Platonic philosophy and new age sensibilities.The abstract sets and stark lighting reflect the film's stage background, but actually work quite well.  Nonetheless, this one probably is more effective on the stage.Mammana is fine as the confused Doug, who starts out as a typical beer-guzzling, meat-eating male.  His performance is sweet and somehow vulnerable as he makes the transformation to sensitive, caring lover.  The real problem with this movie is the character of Guy, or perhaps the performance of Jaeger, who plays him as a prissy, whining, self-righteous neurotic.  He would fit right into a Woody Allen film, except he isn't funny, just annoying.  What Doug sees in him is anybody's guess.Still, with all its faults, this is an interesting film and worth seeing, if only for the performance of Mammana.

reviewText: No explosions, no car chases, no special effects....no, we are definitely not in Hollywood anymore!Just Say Love clearly illustrates what is missing from almost all big Hollywood movies--a real story.  With Just Say Love, story and characters are everything.With two characters and settings without much significance, the story moves to the forefront.  The story is even simple--but profound.  I read somewhere that someone thought is was just another hopeless gay film about a gay "guy" stupidly in love with a straight man.  That could not be farther from the truth.This is a film that can be taken at face value.  It is all about people finding their place in the puzzle of life.  It is all about finding breathing room to grow into ourselves and to be surrounded by people who accept who we start out as and who we finish as.  It's about following one destiny and letting other destinies find us.On the other side, this movie is all about not allowing traditional structures become building plans for life.This is a simple movie that is simply wonderful.
summary: Good stories stand on their own
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is an adaptation of the stage play and is directed by Bill Humphreys. He has taken the very brave move to play this straight (no pun intended), in that it is almost a straight filmatic version of the stage play. It is shot all in a blacked out sound stage with the various sets all in view to begin with.The basic plot is that Guy (Mathew Jaeger) is reading Plato on a park bench, when the sweaty carpenter Doug (Robert Mammana) comes up sits down to have his lunch with a gassy beer and starts a conversation. He then goes on to proposition him for some après lunch oral exercise in the bushes. They do seem poles apart especially so as Doug admits to being married and having a baby on the way.The relationship develops and what at first springs from sexual desire eventually takes on something more meaningful. The strengths of this film are the inter play with the actors. They are comfortable together even when they are having to be awkward. The direction is minimal as are the sets, which means that they have to be even more engaging - and they really both are.The stage play sets act as an alienation device for the audience, in that you are constantly being reminded of the unreality of the situation - but that is exactly what happens in a play anyway. The stage devices are a bit off putting like eating when there is clearly no food in the bowl and the set echoes in places. However, there is a well done love scene that then lapses into arty shots that are also unrealistic. Let's face it after some man on man coital activities, you don't start doing naked catalogue poses - at least I don't. This though is an exploration of the psychology of love and all else is a part player. In that the film succeeds, it is not rushed and the tale is simple but engaging.If you are a fan of gay cinema then this take will be of interest to you, the ending may leave some feeling that Ms Blyton had a hand in the script, but it is just an ending to a new beginning and I did not mind when I watched it. At 75 mins this will hold your attention, but is probably one to rent as I would not be falling over myself for a second coming - I mean viewing (what am I like?)
summary: Two Men, A Park Bench, Beer - Stuff Will Happen!
Title: N/A

reviewText: For a stage play this is one of the sexy, straightforward and "right in your face" looks at life, friendship, love, marriage and family.  The concept of family is really the focus of this story, looked at from two points of view, with a bit of New Age Hindu nutrition thrown in for spice and variety.  Although "Just Say Love" is a mantra derived from Plato, the characters deal with stereotypes which have grown deep roots within themselves.  Each man is the Shadow, unconscious side, of the other. Synchronicity provides the surprising meaningful connections neither character could expect.  This goes beyond the Platonic view of homosexual relationships.  Alcibiades would be pleased with this outcome.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Personally I loved this film.  It is shot on a stage, but that tends to tie everything together in a way that might be missed otherwise.  The relationship (and love) that develops is genuine, and the way it develops is done very well.  Although the two men appear to be very different, what they want out of life is the same.  And as it turns out, they have something very much in common (revealed at the end of the film).  I have watched this film twice, and it is the kind of movie I could watch again and again.  Don't expect a Hollywood production, just look for a great film with a solid plot, solid characters, and great acting.
Title: N/A
